title: Which team will win the 2015-2016 NBA Finals?
possible_answers: Another team from the Eastern Conference
Another team from the Western Conference
preds:
Joke was on me. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/233807
LeBron & Co proved that forecast maximally wrong
Just for fun burns me again.
Sorry all you bandwagon Ws fans. BELIEVELAND
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and 538.com.

Total score through 6 games in this year’s #NBAFinals
• Warriors: 610
• Cavs: 610
adjusting for home court advantage - 45/55 Cavs

I'm betting on the motivation to make history  (Cavaliers coming back from a 3-1 loss to win championship, first championship for Cleveland).   Warriors have a record 73 wins. 
Lebron James has outplayed Stephen Curry in last two games. Curry is shooting 42%, rushing shots, has been sloppy with defense. 
James has been shooting 51% and has averaged 41 pts in the last two games.  
Draymond Green of the Warriors has been suspended sonce game 4 and that will put more pressure oj Curry.  Of course there's the good old home team advantage which favors the Warriors. But I'm going to take a leap judging from most recent performance and standing motivating factors to forecast Cavaliers have the best chance to win tonight.

GSW Warriors of course......  Last game today 6/19/16.    Cleveland Cavaliers 57 & 25 vs Golden State Warriors 73 & 9. I doubt that Golden State is going to lose 3 in a row particularly with the final game 7 at home. GO WARRIORS. 🏀🏀🏀
due to scoring ability on gsw - can convert their opportunities to points

Game 7. No team has ever come back from 3-1 to win an NBA finals. That said, the Cavs are playing well, and GS is not. But GS is at home for game 7, where they're dang hard to beat. Give GS a 2 in 3 shot to win.
If home court advantage and Cinderella story mean anything in Pro Sports - its now.

FiveThirtyEight mountain of data favors the Warriors to win by 65% vs Cavaliers by 35%.  Cleveland will be the away team on game 7 this coming Sunday. But who can ignore the fact that the Cavaliers have come from a 3-1 game to force a game 7 for the championship?  It has to be a force to reckon with.  I will give the Cavaliers the edge until I can get more info.

Now the series is tied 3-3 and the regular odds are 50-50. However, adjusting for home team advantage and better performance, I adjusted the odds up 15% in GSW's favor. I do not want to fall for the hot hand fallacy or the gambler's fallacy here. The Cavs have had a lot of luck in these two previous games and I expect then to reverse to the mean and have average luck for the final game, so their positive momentum should not interfere in my estimates.

Incredible game last night. One day I will tell my son about what it was like to witness LeBron play. But the Warriors will probably still win the series, because they have home court advantage and the better team.
Forced into Game 7, Winner Take All. All bets are off, this is a 50/50 situation for me.
For Cleveland to win. They need to win Game 6 @Cleveland, a 45% probability and then win Game 7 @GS another 45% probability. Combined probability ~ 20%.
I wanted the Cav's to win so badly that I took the opposite opinion, so that if I was wrong I could still be happy.
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ CLE won away from home, and now trail just 2-3 with two to go. However, they'll have to win both remaining games whereas GSW need just one.
Big win by the Cavs today! Unfortunately for them, still put them at 50/50 for game 6, and if it progresses to game 7, only 25% to win at GS.  Although Bogut out for GS is a big loss.
well, thanks to the Draymond suspension, the Cavs have a real shot now.
Dropping one point on news of Green's suspension
Warriors are playing well and hold a 3-1 lead.

With Green's suspension in Game 5, I have games 5 and 6 at 50/50 and game 7 at 70/30 for GSW. 
This gives the Warriors a 92.5% edge.
Flowing ever with the Great Magnet. Beware the Ides of June.  @Phronesis

Rawk! Rawk! There was a time when giants roamed the Earth. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L2U4JSrpO78 Big athletes that were great basketball players. When players had the heart of a lion not a heart of tin. Such is the time of bread and circuses.

GSW just decisively won game 4, so is now 3 to 1 and going back to play next game in California. 
No team has ever come from behind 3 to 1 to win the NBA championship, but there could be a first time. 
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and 538.com.

https://flipboard.com/@news/the-daily-edition-3adc9613z/james-loses-his-cool-as-cavaliers-pushed-to-the-brink/a-8dsr6KVhSg6W5re2O3B45w%3Aa%3A43591897-61db68fbf0%2Freuters.com
Lebron losing his cool - never a good sign.

Adjusting my forecast with yesterday's result. Now there is a 87.5% probability that GSW will win at least one of the next 7 games assuming equal chance of each outcome. Besides that, GSW have a home advantage, playing two of the next 3 games at home. Finally, there is an advantage for having a better team during regular season. With this in mind, I boosted the difference to 15 p.p. on top of the 87.5/12.5 resulting in odds of 95/5 in GSW's favor.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/
GSW now lead 3-1 and need just one out of the remaining three to claim the title. Next game is at home.
I have them at .7 to win at home and 0.5 to win away. This means that the chance of them losing the next 3 is 0.3*0.5*0.3 which is 4.5%
Love's back. Over in 5. The Love-Affect.
I think the Cavs have a ~50% chance of taking it to 6,  a ~10% chance of taking it to 7, and a 0% chance of winning the title.

Home team usually wins - GSW has major home field advantage, so at 95% on that. But CLE better than average home opponent in 2015/16, so drop that to 85%. Then add Curry appearing to be less than top form, so drop to 75%. With Love seemingly on the bench CLE playing different better, so adjust after game 4.

At this point, GSW is leading 2-1, which would give them a natural probability of 68.75%, assuming equal probabilities of each possible outcome for the next games. Home is not a  with even number of games left. But I will bump the numbers up because GSW seem to have a better team based on it's relative performance on the regular season (71 wins vs 53) and on the direct matches between both teams in the regular season (2-1). I considered that performance advantage as a 10% difference in favor of GSW.
Cavs up very slightly on the strength of last night's win. Warriors still heavily favored, but with Love coming off of the bench, the Cavs have a chance.
Love-Affect. Meaning they are better off without Love. Better D, no surprise. Better O, actually a surprise.
Golden State edge it on almost every metric in terms of the statistics, and are coming out of a record season. That said, Cavs have just shown in game 3 that nothing is for certain.

Still following 538. 
GSW now lead 2-1, CLE having pulled one back at home. The next game is also on CLE's home court.
I initially predicted Warriors in 7, and the results so far are consistent with that outcome. But the Cavs are not looking like a team that can steal a game at Oracle, or even win 3 at home.

After two impressive victories at home in Oakland, the Cleveland Cavaliers have their work cut out for them. The likelihood of prevailing has diminished greatly. Nevertheless, to prevail the Cavaliers now must win four games in five to prevail. Unlikely.

Deadspin is super bitchy, and also as good as it gets challenging conventional wisdom of sports - so much in sports journalism more a reaction than thoughtful analysis. How good is Kyrie? Indeed. http://deadspin.com/how-good-is-kyrie-irving-really-1780806442?utm_campaign=socialflow_deadspin_twitter&utm_source=deadspin_twitter&utm_medium=socialflow Cavs looked better last year in the finals. Losing Love may actually help them. Now they need to lose Kyrie. He looks healthy, so I'm almost all-in for GSW.

Only 3 times out of 31 has a team down 2-0 in the Finals come back to win it all. Thats a shade under 10%, however I assume in a lot of those cases the team that was down 2-0 looked competitive in the first few games and lost fairly close games. Not the case for the Cavs in the first few games, plus they're facing the possibility of Love being out with a concussion.
Only question now, will LeBron re-follow the Cavs?
Only three travels for Lebron in the first half and two for Irving.

Based on past NBA Finals, 94.6% of teams (with homecourt advantage) who is up 2-0 wins the series. [1] For this specific series, FiveThirtyEight.com gives an 89% chance to GSW to win the title. [2] [1] http://www.whowins.com/tables/up20.html
[2] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/

As per Khalid GSW lead 2-0. CLE would have to win 4 out of the remaining 5 to take the title.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ GSW lead 2-0. CLE would have to win 4 out of the remaining 5 to take the title.
Game 7, if it happens, is at home for GSW.

GSW just decisively won game 2.

Favoring GSW more heavily after the win in game 1, though I still think the series will likely go to 7 games (possibly 6 if the Cavs play like that at home too).
Updated now that GS has won game 1.

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and 538.com.
SGW are obviously the favourite, and they beat the Cavs last year.  The Warriors ar ebetter than they are last year too, while the Cavs are maybe just a bit better or the same.

Can Golden State overcome the traveling LeBrons's? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VcWn7edyi_k  NSFW Language.  It's all my fault for getting into a question where the refs are a minor step up from Pro Wrestling.

The Cavs would have had a much better shot against the Thunder, but GS are undefeated against the Cavs in their past 6 matches (including Summer League game), and match up well against them. Will take a herculean effort from LeBron for the Cavs to win.

For Cavs: GSW on short rest, Lebron won two games by himself last year in the finals, Kyrie + Love are back, Channing Frye addition allows Cavs to matchup well in terms of 3pt shooting, had a historically good playoff run so far, Cavs have had lots of rest and seem to be gelling at the right moment For GSW: GSW home court advantage, have gotten better since last year, team is mostly healthy, Klay and Curry the best shooting backcourt in NBA

Cavs are much stronger than last year, when they took it to 6 games. I fully expect this year's series to go to 7. Warriors have home court advantage + better regular season record, which gives them a slight edge (but not as large as the consensus, I'm estimating).
Updated forecast now that GS have qualified for the finals
Curry makes a lot of bad shots. How do they go in? Unreal.
Much respect to OKC, 2nd best team in the league :)  Series really could have gone either way.   Now for a repeat of last year's championship round.  Bring it home Woyas! @nrohr @wchang
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and 538.com.
Slight edge to Warriors in game 7 due to home court.

I arrived at these odds based on the following: For Western Conf Game 7, I figure Golden State should be a clear but not overwhelming favorite.
GSW vs OKC: 60%GSW, 40% OKC In the Finals, I'd give Golden State a big advantage, having proven their strength all season long and with a huge series comeback. I think Cleveland would be more evenly matched with Oklahoma City.
CLE vs GSW: 65%GSW, 35% CLE
CLE vs OKC: 50% CLE, 50%OKC Also, I bumped Golden State up a percentage point because Steph Curry is Steph Curry.
The Thunder seem to be losing momentum based on 538.com.
I'm starting to hate this question.
Cleveland is in, the Warriors are at home for Game 7 (big benefit), but it's game 7 and the Thunder could pull an upset.  Lots on uncertainty in the West right now.
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ GSW have won their last two games and are now tied with OKC 3-3, with one to go.
Also, zeroing out East Other, and dropping Cavs a bit.
Big game by Klay tonite!  Swapping GSW and OKC again, as GSW gets game 7 at home.
Wish I could post pictures of OKC fans' faces now but I'm confident the Internet will take care of that. Feel bad for KD.
Just trying to stay active out there
The script calls for GSW to lose the next game.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/
Warriors pulled one back from the Thunder, now trailing 3-2 and must win both remaining matches. Raptors in the same  boat, trailing 2-3 to the Cavaliers. Contrary to initial expectations, this is turning out to be a nail-biter, but CLE and OKC just need to win one out of two to reach the finals.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/
Cavaliers leading Raptors 3-1.
Warriors 1-3 down to the Thunder, it's do or die for them tonight.
bumping EC up ahead of game 5 - solely because I'm a fan

Down 3-1 to the Thunder, there's no way the Warriors can still be the Title favorites. Historically, teams come back from down 3-1 less than 5% of the time, but these are the 73-9 Warriors so I'm not that pessimistic. They still though after accomplishing that need to go on and win another series, so
Swapping OKC and GSW's probs.  GSW is not dead yet, but is clear underdog now.  Also, not as sure anymore that Cleveland has an edge on OKC either.

hometown advantage for potential deciding game - don't like to underestimate the energy of the crowd - it really can change outcomes also changing GSW to practically no chance at this point - I admit this is going out on a limb but adjusting for being 2 games down without the home court advantage when they were faves was just a huge error on GSW part which was unforeseen. Still don't think raptors can take it all the way so leaving the final with OKC vs CC with OKC taking it.
OKC vs CC but I really want it to be OKC vs Raptors go r, go!

9 teams have come back from 3-1. 220-9 (.961). http://www.whowins.com/tables/up31.html  Bad odds. Tired from the 73? If any team can beat the odds, GSW can. But from what I've seen, OKC is too fast for them. I'm giving max respect giving the Warriors 10%.  Moving on, I can see LeBron eating the backpack kids' lunch.
Thunder beat Warriors again, now lead 3-1. Latest predictions http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/
Most champions are no. 1 seed.  GSW has now a very slim chance of even getting to the finals.

Best case scenario for GSW: 
P(GSW wins game 5) = .7 
P(GSW wins game 6) = .4 
P(GSW wins game 7) = .7 
==> P(GSW makes final) = .7*.7*.4 ~= .2
P(GSW wins final ) = 0.2*.66 ~=0.13
This means that there is an 87% chance that OKC makes the final. I have them as slight favorites over Cleveland (having beaten San Antonio and OKC) and there is a small outside chance that Toronto upsets Cleveland. But even then, I have them as huge underdogs...
Up 2-1 the Thunder have a legit chance to knock off the Warriors. At the very least they have shown the Warriors aren't invincible, so beating the Cavs isn't a foregone conclusion.

Shifting a lot of probability to the Raps and Thunder. OKC now has homecourt advantage and they just look like they can take this series. I don't think GSW will have shooting nights like game 3 in games 4-7, but OKC has shown they're capable.  The Cavs still have homecourt advantage and thus I'm favoring them over the Raps much more. I think the Raps can take it to 6 or 7 games, but it's still more likely than not that they lose (and if they make the finals, they're a huge long shot against either GSW or OKC). Two questions:
1. When will LeBron forget about all of this team-first ball and take over? It seems like either Love, Irving, or both are having an off night every game now, and the rest of the Cavs starters and bench aren't providing much help. Love and J.R. Smith were both pretty terrible last night. 2. Is Green's non-suspension actually better for OKC? They seem to play better when angry. @wchang @GJDrew

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/
Raptors and Cavaliers are 2-2, Thunder lead Warriers 2-1! For comparison, http://www.oddschecker.com/basketball/nba have GSW at 40%, CLE 37, Thunders 21 and Raptors 2.
The Thunder seem to be gaining momentum based on 538.com.
Just going by what Nate says by now, more of less: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/
Rationale: wish I could lower my forecast for the east. Hope everyone's wrong and the finals are good.
Claiming an accident. Dream on Draymond.   A likely suspension will make it super hard for for GSW.
Getting uncomfortably close again, as a GSW fan.
Wow, the base rate for leading 2:1 in the NBA semis is 0.8 to win the series: http://www.whowins.com/tables/up21.html

GSW lost to OKC again, now down 2-1 overall. Probabilities per http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ who had given this outcome a 56% chance. For comparison, best odds on Oddschecker are GSW 13/10, CLe 7/5, Thunder 7/2 and Raptors 200/1. http://www.oddschecker.com/basketball/nba . That makes GSW about 40%, CLE 39% , Thunder 21% and Raptors 0.
However, I'm staying with 538 because I suspect the bookies haven't caught up with the latest game results.
Backing Khalid's prediction, I need a reliable method to predict sporting results. ELO ratings seems reasonable. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/240580

Using http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ Bookmakers odds are somewhat different http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ They have GSW 4/9,  CLE 31/20, Thunder 7/1 and Raptors anywhere between 50/1 and 250/1, which would take GSW up to 51%, Cavaliers increased to 38, and Thunder down to 11. For now I'll stick with 538 but perhaps next time I'll take the mean of the two.
Six game final. The King chokes, again.
Cleveland has deeper bench this year

Toronto is done, would probably need at this point a season ending injury to Lebron, plus one other starter to win the East, then they'd have to beat either Golden State or the Thunder. Chances of all that happening are well under 1%.
Raising Cavs, lowering Raps to 0% and lowering GSW by 2% on the strength of the Cavs' wins.

No change, but just noting Nate Silver's probs   http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ Cavs: 28%
GSW: 45%
TOR: 3%
OKC: 24% I'm not that far from them, but they're dissing the Cavs!  @nrohr @wchang
Nudging the Warriors up 1% and the Thunder down 1%. OKC looked great in game 1, but now that the series is even they have to win 3 of 5 , including game 5 at GSW.

Ok, I have GSW and OKC even after 4 games with a probability of .5*.5*2 and up 3-1 with prob .5^2= 0.25 and down 3-1 with prob 0.25... This leads to a rough estimate of GSW beating OKC with probability 60% and then beating Cleveland with probability 65%. 
If OKC beats GSW, I have them at 50-50 against CLE... The rest belongs to CLE.
Do better Raptors or else I'm going to have to downgrade you.

Realized I could (for now) not back down from ripping on LeBron while giving OKC props for winning game 1...
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/233807

Just one game, but OKC up 1-0 on Warriors has to count for something. I like the Thunder's chances against the Cavs in the Finals, even though I believe they got swept in the season series. Thunder seem to be a different\better team in these playoffs than we would have thought.

Thunder are clearly better than we all think.  It is only one game, but the game was on the road in GS.  I still feel that either the thunder or GS will beat the cavs, and I give the cavs little chance of losing in their semis.

Even after a game 1 loss, I have the warriors at 50-50 to beat the thunder (I admit this may be a little high). If they do, then I have them at 65-35 to beat the Cavs (this puts them at about 33% to win the title). OKC on the other hand, I have at 50-50 against Cleveland (seems to me like Cleveland would match up well with OKC's big lineups), giving OKC about 25% total. The rest belongs to Cleveland (after slight subjective adjustments).  Will continually readjust as the series progress...

Coach Steve Kerr has one of the most amazing "Basketball Minds" from having both lived and breathed the game for so long.  His experience winning championships both as a player of the Chicago Bulls & the San Antonio Spurs, as well as last year's NBA Championship coaching Golden State makes them my "odds on favorite" to repeat this year (providing all their players remain injury free).

I have no idea about the teams but with just four left I'm jumping to add some excitement. Basically following 538's predictions, but with an eye on betting odds. The latter still have GSW as most likely to win, though no longer the odds on favorite they were yesterday. http://www.oddschecker.com/basketball/nba/nba-championship/winner

Most NBA champions are No. 1 seed. [1]   But... OKC defeats GSW in game 1 which gives them an edge for the whole series. Teams that leads 1-0 on best of 7 games and wins at opponents home court during Conference finals wins 71.4%. [2]
Teams that leads 1-0 on best of 7 games during Conference finals, all courts wins 79.7% of the time.  [2]
Teams that leads 1-0 on a best of 7 games wins 77% all series, all courts, first round to finals. [2] 
Teams that leads 1-0 on best of 7 games and wins at opponents home court wins 54.3%.  [2] [1] https://sportslistoftheday.com/2012/03/30/nba-finals-winners-by-seed/
[2] http://www.whowins.com/tables/up10.html
Ouch.  OKC takes game 1 at GS.  Raising them from 10% to 22%.   Western Conference finals is gonna be a war.  @nrohr @wchang
GSW, after not allowing more than 106 points in any of the first 7 playoff games, has now given up 120 or more points in each of the last 3 games against the 5 th ranked team in its conference.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and 538.com.

WC and EC chances roughly half what they were before now only one team from each survived (OKC, Raptors, but stronger showing from both the underdogs based on team stats before and after playoffs quarterfinals than expected.  go raptors

My earlier prediction was wrong (I picked San Antonio and am still shocked). I didn't realize that we were allowed to keep submitting new predictions on questions we've participated in. Seems wrong somehow, but I'm doing it, for the first and maybe last time.
Well...Spurs are out. Curry looks like he's coming back from injury without complication, so I'd say it's more likely than not Golden State wins it all at this point.

The Thunder blasted the Spurs 113-99 Thursday night at Chesapeake Arena to win this Western Conference semifinal series that started with a blowout...Thunder Routed the Spurs.
http://newsok.com/peake-form/article/5497838?newsletter=daily-dynamic-email

Welp. Not many saw OKC taking that series (Chris Broussard though, apparently). I have the Cavs at 30% vs. GSW and 50% vs. OKC. The latter would have been lower a week ago, but OKC is looking strong. I have OKC at 30% against the Warriors. That means 36% Cavs, 49% GSW, and 15% OKC. I took 1% from the Cavs to hedge against some tiny possibility that Toronto or Miami pulls out a miracle.
My rationale is this forecast is just too fun to make because of that car commercial about LeBron and probabilities.

Down goes the Spurs!  OKC is a good team but will have a tough time getting past both GSW and Cleveland.  They're underdogs to both.  No more than 33% chance each.  So .3*.33 ~= 10%.  GSW is favored against both probably around .7 * .7 =~50%.  Rest goes to Cleveland.

Note re (probably) failed forecast rationale: Thought the Spurs could beat Golden State. (In the only regular season game the Spurs gave them a real look, Golden State got beat, largely by Diaw, who Pop benched the next game vs. GSW with a phantom injury...(It seems to me the Spurs frequently play possum with the good teams during the reg season via benching good players/matchup advantages against teams they think could win the championship)). Looks like the Spurs probably won't get to play Golden State now.... This forecasting problem will not go well for me... OKC's played a good series.
Stats look very similar to last year.  Only the  potential for injury to Steph Curry will give the Cavaliers a chance.
Spurs are really struggling with the thunder, clearly curry is back strong, and the cavs are the clear favorite in the east
My rationale is currently not very sophisticated. I considered the outside view base winning percentages for both the CLE and GSW teams, then looked at the inside view details from recent games.

OKC - WC
Toronto - EC
San Antonio falling behind in stats

OKC up 3-2. Increasing odds on OKC (decreasing SA) due to prior under weighting.
Consensus lists SA as almost 10 times more likely than OKC to win the finals, even though OKC leads the series between the two.

@GJDrew I think OKC is favored over the Spurs now, though not by a bunch. Here are my conditional calculations: East: Cavs will win and advance to finals. 0% chance Toronto or Miami beats Cleveland in the ECF. West: GSW 70%, OKC 17%, SAS 13% to win WCF Finals:
Cavs 30/70 GSW
Cavs 55/45 OKC
Cavs 45/55 SAS That means:
Cavs (vs. GSW): .3*.7= .21
Cavs (vs. OKC) .55*.17 = .0935
Cavs (vs. SAS) .45*.13 = .0585
total = .36 GSW .7 * .7 = .49
OKC .45*.17 = .08
SAS .55 * .13 = .07 Curious what others think about these probabilities.

Taking San Antonio down 17% because they're in a bit of trouble down 3-2 in the series, but I still like their chances to pull it out in 7. If they do they're still a very viable team to win it all. Cleveland has been looking strong, so I've bumped them up 8% with some of what I took from San Antonio. Increased West, since a Thunder win over the Spurs makes them more likely to win it all. Only bumped Warriors up 6% (but now my favorites to win it all), because although after a slow start Curry had a phenomenal finish, I'm being cautious with his injury. How did he feel the next day etc, particularly since he probably played more minutes because of overtime than they would have liked him to in his first game back. If they had wanted him to play 37 minutes they would have started him instead of bringing him off the bench.
Bad news for SA good news for GS and LeBron

What a difference a game makes. Spurs can still win it in 7, but OKC now has the chance to close it out at home.  They've gone from underdogs to slight faves in that series. Their chances against GSW is about the same as the Spurs.  I like the Spurs chances against Cleveland better than OKC though.  So SA is still slightly ahead of OKC for championship.   Clevelands and GSW chances also move up slightly.  @nrohr @wchang
The Spurs are reeling, OKC looks gritty, Seth Curry was not accidentally picked as MVP: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/
I was pretty high on the Spurs. Now they have to win their next two so I am down to 0 until they make it out of this series.
He's back: Curry lays a young 40 on Portland.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5NuofNHKbVc

Down 16. Win by 7.  Curry missed his first nine 3-pointers. Yea, just like everyone plans. They win with Curry. They win without Curry. They win without optimal Curry. They just win. No one  has the horses to beat GSW 4 out of 7.  LeBron is otherworldly, but who unfollows his own team? He's been preparing for the madhouse all year. And for good reason. Hey Kyrie, try passing to the best player in the world. The anti-GSW.  (insert Trump's 'sad').
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and 538.com.

GSW should knock off Blazers soon, OKC-Spurs could go 7. Draymond has been nothing short of amazing. Short-rested Spurs will not fare well against GSW with fully-rested Curry (although he might be more injured than the team is letting on). Cavs clicking at just the right moment-- last year they took GSW to six games w/o Love or Kyrie. Both Love and Kyrie are healthy (for now) and their next round matchup might be banged up following a potentially long series.
Steph Curry's health keeping GSW at only 75%.

The Cavs are looking great. It's hard to say if all of the team chemistry issues reported in the media over the season were actually a problem, but anyway it doesn't look like any of that is going on now. No one in the East can stop them. They're about to get another long break and they'll go up against the Raps with injured/missing JV or the Heat with injured/missing Whiteside, coming off of a difficult and likely 7-game series. The Thunder are looking much, much better against the Spurs than I anticipated. I can't tell if the Thunder are playing better than expected or the Spurs worse. I'm inclined to go with the latter. Golden state warriors would have been the default championship with 100% surety. They have a very good team.  But without Stephen curry they lose their edge. If Curry is not back in the next playoff series the conference semifinals, the warriors are done for. Clippers could beat Warriors without Curry. Spurs, Cavaliers and OKC are the alternatives to battle it out if warriors are eliminated. Popovich is one of the best coaches in the league. Given similarly talented teams Popovich will prevail.

The Spurs winning of 67 games was over shadowed by the Warrior's historic season, but the teams are fairly evenly matched. The Warriors would have the edge except for Curry's injury. Although I expect the Warriors are good enough to make it a few weeks without Curry, there are many unknowns. He could be out longer, could reinjure himself, could come back rusty from a long layoff. With the injuries to the Clippers, I don't feel the remaining teams in the West are much stronger than the East. I give a slight edge to the West, because I feel they have the next most dangerous team in the Thunder.

There will be 16 teams in the NBA playoffs. In the last 10 years, we've seen two Finals won by a team that wasn't a first or second seed from one of the conferences. I'll put an 80% baseline chance for one of the "top four" teams to win. 30% for Hawks plus Cavaliers, 50% for Warriors plus Spurs (given the respective records of the teams). The Cavaliers are a bit better than the Hawks, and the Warriors are a bit better than the Spurs. (These are both close, though!) So that makes me want to say ~18% for the Cavs, ~28% for the Warriors, ~22% for the Spurs, and divide the rest between the other teams in the conferences. But looking over the Finals history, the huge disparity in records between Golden State/San Antonio and the rest of the Western Conference is, if not unprecedented, at least unusual. I think both of those teams deserve a bit more credit, especially since the Warriors feel like a "team of destiny" this year. I'll give the Warriors points that I take away from others. The sad thing is, I have this feeling in my gut that the Warriors will stomp to victory and I'll feel silly for having given some third-rate Eastern Conference squad even a 1/1000 chance. But I'll force myself to stick within the bounds of reason.
Defense is for baseball and football.  Basketball is all about shooting.  This year that is the Warriors.
Cavs can prevail in 7 game's. The warriors are worthy runner up but defense will still win the championship.The playoffs get much more physical  Cavs have the edge in bigs.

For everyone giving the Warriors a high probability -
The playoffs haven't even started so you have to look at the road to the finals. The West is much more challenging than the East. Imagine the likely scenario where the Warriors play the Spurs in the Western Conference Finals and the Cavs in the Finals. Give a probability to each of those series and multiply them together. And then remember that there are four rounds of playoffs. Furthermore, "Another team from the Western Conference" includes the Thunder.  I know the Cavs are still looking for themselves, but their path to the finals is so much easier. Don't look at the ESPN power rankings and the experts, think about the overall road. That's why I give the Cavs the biggest probability pre-playoffs, and I'll adjust as each round of the playoffs go by.
Three best teams are in the West. I would pick OKC over Cleveland. And no one else in the East worth a look.

I don't believe GSW can win a 7 game series against the Spurs.  The West is just so competitive that any of the top 4 teams could compete for the title, while the East only seems to have a couple of teams that are dominate. That being said I wouldn't bet the house on any of the favorites.

Eastern Conference in general is weaker, seems less likely they get the eventual champ unless it's the Cavs. Warriors are the obvious favorite, but have dropped important games to teams they will need to beat to get back to the championship. Because of that the Spurs or another team (Clippers/Thunder) seem to be next in line.

No change, but just noting 538's forecast right now (March 28): http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nba-picks/ Warriors: 42%.  San Antonio: 29%.  Cleveland: 9%.  Other East: 12%.  Other West: 8%.

GSW are clearly the favorites as they have demonstrated on their historic run. The only things that could derail them are significant injury to Curry or Thompson, and even that might not be enough. San Antonio is the only team in the West that has a chance at beating them in a 7-game series. The Cavs could lose in the EC playoffs, but it would be very unlikely for Toronto or another East team that won the EC finals to beat the Warriors or Spurs in the finals.

No other team can compete with the Warriors or Spurs at home, and while the Warriors are currently playing as a better team, they have not beaten the Spurs in San Antonio for several games. The warriors should eventually come out on top to repeat their performance last year, barring injuries.

Warriors favored, Spurs next.  Cleveland is falling apart and isn't much better than another Eastern Conference contender.  Another Western Conference team (e.g. OKC, Clippers) only has a real chance if they don't have to play both Spurs and Warriors.  If they have to play both, that's a hard road to the championship.
Clearly the best team in the league, barring catastrophic injury
